isis.stitle: DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service (1990) - VIBRATION DAMPER, CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE - CRANKCASE (RECONDITIONING) - INSTALLATION

note.para: PRIOR TO CRANKSHAFT INSTALLATION, INSPECT THE CRANKCASE AS DESCRIBED LATER IN THIS SECTION.
Refer to "SPECIFICATIONS" for proper main bearing width.

step1.para: Rotate the engine so the main bearing saddles are facing upward.
Wipe the main bearing support using a lint-free cloth. The supports must be free of oil. DO NOT LUBRICATE THE BACK SIDE OF THE BEARING INSERTS.

Install upper bearing inserts into bearing saddle. Be sure locking tangs on bearings are snapped into crankcase. Refer to Figure 7.61
.
Apply Prussian Blue(r) to the crankshaft main bearing journals. Carefully lower the crankshaft onto the main bearing inserts in the crankcase.

note.para: Do not install the main bearing caps and lower bearing inserts at this time.

step1.para: Rotate the crankshaft 1/2 turn.
Carefully remove the crankshaft and inspect the upper bearing inserts for an even transfer of bluing from the journals to the bearings.

note.para: IF VOIDS APPEARED IN BLUING TRANSFER, CRANKCASE INTEGRITY IS QUESTIONABLE.

step1.para: When satisfied that the crankcase is in good order and free of distortion and burrs around the upper bearing insert seats, clean all Prussian Blue(r) from the bearings and crankshaft journals.

Lubricate the upper main bearing inserts with clean engine oil. Refer to Figure 7.62
.

Carefully install the crankshaft into the main bearing saddle. Use the SE-2722 lifting sling to lower the crankshaft. Refer to Figure 7.63
.

svcsubproc.title: New Main Bearing Cap Fitting Procedure for Service
svcsubproc.para: A crankcase can usually be salvaged even if a main bearing cap has been damaged. Replacement main bearing caps are available for service. The bore of these caps is finish machined, which eliminates the need of line boring after installation. However, the face and sides of the caps must be modified to the dimensions of the old cap to assure a perfect fit in the crankcase. Enough material has been left on the face and sides of the caps to allow for this modification.
Following are detailed instructions for modifying caps.

step1.para:
Replacement main bearing caps require the face and sides of the caps to be machined to the dimension of the old cap. We will refer to the face and sides as surfaces "A","B" and,"C". Refer to Figure 7.64
.
Surface "A" modification:

step2.para:
Measure the distance from the face of the cap to the saddle. We refer to this as dimension No. 1. See Figure 7.65
.

Measuring the old cap first, place a drill rod or a new drill of any size from 6 to 13 mm (1/4 to 1/2 in.) on the cap saddle. Measure the distance from the face of the cap ( Figure 7.66
) to the drill rod shank with a depth gauge as shown and record the reading.

note.para: Repeat this procedure on the service cap and record the reading. If the old cap is broken and dimension No. 1 cannot be determined, use one of the other caps as a pattern.
USE THE SAME DRILL BIT FOR ALL MEASUREMENTS OF DIMENSION NO. 1, 2 AND 3.

step2.para: Calculate dimension No.1 as follows: Subtract the original cap dimension from the service cap dimension. Then subtract an additional 0.051 mm (0.002 in.)
(Service Cap Dim. - Original Cap Dim.) - 0.051 mm (0.002 in.) = Material to be removed from surface "A".

note.para: Two thousandths of an inch is subtracted to allow enough stock for a finish cut.

step2.para: Mill or grind the back of the cap until the surface is flat. Verify flatness after machining.

Now modify surface "A" by machining the appropriate amount of material calculated in step c above. Refer to Figure 7.67
.

note.para: VERIFY THAT PROPER AMOUNT OF MATERIAL WAS REMOVED AND CHECK FOR FLATNESS.

step1.para: Surface "B" modification: (Notched side of cap).

step2.para:
Calculate dimension No. 2, prior to modifying surface "B". Refer to Figure 7.68
.

Clamp the old main bearing cap to a surface plate. Place a drill rod of any size from 6 to 13 mm (1/4 to 1/2 in.) on the inside of the cap (against the notched side). Measure the distance with a micrometer as shown in Figure 7.69
. Record the reading.

note.para: Repeat this procedure on the service cap.

step2.para: Calculate dimension No. 2 as follows: Subtract the original cap dimension from the service cap dimension.
Service Cap Dim. - Original Cap Dim. = Material to be removed from surface "B".

Modify surface "B" to an angle plate with surface "B" facing up. Mill or grind the appropriate amount of material, calculated in step c, from surface "B" ( Figure 7.70
).

note.para: SURFACE "B" MUST BE HELD SQUARE WITH SURFACE "A" AND PARALLEL TO THE BEARING BORE.

step1.para: Surface "C" modification:

step2.para:
Calculate dimension No. 3, prior to modifying surface "C". Refer to Figure 7.71
.

Using a 177.8 mm (7.0 in.) micrometer, measure the width of the service cap as shown in Figure 7.72
.

note.para: The specification for dimension No. 3 is 154 mm +/- 0.03 mm (6.051 in. +/- 0.001 in.).

step2.para: Calculate the amount of material to be removed to obtain dimension No. 3 as follows: Subtract the specification 154 mm (6.051 in.) from the service cap width.
Service Cap Width - 153.69 mm (6.051 in.) = Material to be removed from Surface "C".

figure.caption: Figure 7.72. Measure Dimension No. 3 (Bearing Cap Width).

note.para: SURFACE "C" MUST BE HELD SQUARE WITH SURFACE "A" AND PARALLEL TO THE BEARING BORE.

step1.para: Demagnetize the bearing cap after machining.
Remove all burrs and sharp edges with a file or a deburring tool. Clean the cap in soap and water to remove all machining oil.
Install a new bearing in a new bearing cap or in the original bearing cap, as required. Be sure the locking tangs on the bearing inserts are snapped into the bearing cap notch.
Check bearing clearance as follows:

step2.para: Clean the bearing surface and the exposed half of the crankshaft journal. Be sure these surfaces are free of oil.
Install the bearing caps and lower inserts and tighten to the specified torque.
Remove bearing cap with insert, one at a time. Remaining caps are left tight while checking fit of bearing with cap removed.
Wipe the oil from all contact surfaces of the exposed journal and bearing insert and cap removed.

Place Plastigage(r) across the full width of the bearing surface on the crankshaft journal (or bearing cap insert) approximately 6.4 mm (0.25 in.) off center. Install bearing cap and tighten cap bolt to special torque.

note.para: Do not turn crankshaft while making check with Plastigage(r).

IN CHASSIS SERVICE ONLY - When bearing clearance is checked, the crankshaft will have to be supported and held against the upper main bearing halves to get a correct Plastigage(r) reading. Use a jack at counterweight next to each main bearing being checked to support the crankshaft. Failure to support the crankshaft will result in inaccurate readings.

step2.para: Remove bearing cap with insert.

Do not disturb Plastigage(r). Using the Plastigage(r) envelope, measure the widest point of the Plastigage(r), ( Figure 7.74
). This reading indicates the bearing clearance in thousandths of an inch or millimeters.
If the bearing clearance is not within specifications, the crankshaft must be replaced or reground and undersize bearings installed (as described earlier in this section).

step1.para: With acceptable bearing clearance, proceed as follows:

step2.para: Clean Plastigage(r) from the bearing or crankshaft journal surface.
Coat all bearing surface journals and bolts with clean engine oil.
Place the #1-6 bearing caps with lower bearing inserts over the crankshaft in the proper location.

note.para: The crankcase and main bearing caps were marked as shown in Figure 7.75. When installing the caps be sure the numbers match on the crankcase and the cap. Some bearing caps may have the number stamped on either side of the arrow, however, when installing the bearing cap the arrow must point toward the camshaft side.

step2.para:
Tighten the #1-6 main bearing cap bolts to the specified torque. Refer to Figure 7.76
.

figure.caption: Figure 7.75. Verify Proper Bearing Cap Location.

step1.para: Install the rear thrust bearing as follows:

step2.para:
Insert the main bearing cap with the rear thrust bearing in position as shown in Figure 7.77
.
Center the rear thrust bearing by moving the crankshaft rearward, then forward.

Tighten the two rear thrust bearing bolts finger-tight then tighten to the specified torque. Refer to Figure 7.78
.

step1.para:
Check crankshaft end play using a dial indicator as follows: Refer to Figure 7.79
.

step2.para: Mount the dial indicator on the crankcase with the indicator tip on the crankcase flange face.
Lightly pry the crankshaft forward and "zero" the indicator.
Then pry the crankshaft rearward and record the dial indicator reading. Repeat to assure an accurate reading.

note.para: If end play exceeds the specifications, replace the thrust bearing and recheck crankshaft end play.

figure.caption: Figure 7.77. Install Rear Thrust Bearing Cap and Insert.

step1.para: Install the piston and rod assemblies. Refer to CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS, RINGS AND SLEEVES.
Install the front plate and front cover. Refer to TIMING GEAR TRAIN AND FRONT COVER.
Install oil pump assembly. Refer to LUBRICATING OIL PUMP, OIL FILTERS AND COOLER.
